revision.text:
The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents''': {{dynamic list}} {{toc right}} [[File:Offthepipe.JPG|thumb|right|250 px]]
== Belgium == * 2004: A major [[natural gas]] pipeline exploded in [[Ghislenghien]], [[Belgium]] near [[Ath]] (50 kilometres southwest of [[Brussels]]), killing 24 people and leaving 122 wounded, some critically on July 30, 2004<ref name="iab-atex.nl">{{cite web|url=http://www.iab-atex.nl/publicaties/database/Ghislenghien%20Dossier.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724154332/http://www.iab-atex.nl/publicaties/database/Ghislenghien%20Dossier.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-24 |df= }}</ref>
== Canada == * 1962: An explosion on a gas pipeline occurred on a lateral line on January 17, about 50 kilometers northwest of [[Edson, Alberta]]. 8 people were killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edmontonjournal.com/1962+Eight+dead+four+injured+explosion/7823967/story.html|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20130215215441/http://www.edmontonjournal.com/1962+Eight+dead+four+injured+explosion/7823967/story.html|deadurl=yes|title=Jan. 16, 1962: Eight dead, four injured in gas explosion|date=15 February 2013|archivedate=15 February 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1946&dat=19620117&id=3o4jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=z50FAAAAIBAJ&pg=6178,2472719|title=The Montreal Gazette - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> * 1965: An explosion from a gas line destroyed several apartments in the [[LaSalle Heights Disaster]] in [[LaSalle, Quebec]] killing 28 people, the worst pipeline disaster in Canadian history * 1965: On October 12, an explosion & fire involved the Albert Gas Trunk Line LTD. near [[Sundre, Alberta]], killing 2 pipeline workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19651013&id=lTk0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=bfUIAAAAIBAJ&pg=3622,452027|title=Ottawa Citizen - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> * 1969: On October 25, a faulty pipe exploded in a gas line beneath [[Malton, Ontario]]. One person died, about 20 were injured, 9 stores and several homes were destroyed. Gas in a dead end section of gas pipeline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insauga.com/the-day-malton-blew-up |title=The Day Malton Blew Up | Mississauga |publisher=insauga.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 1986: On October 27, a butane pipeline was hit by a pipeline crew, in [[Sarnia, Ontario]]; 4 workers were injured (one critically).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1946&dat=19861028&id=m1kiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=S6gFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3568,4211494&hl=en|title=The Montreal Gazette - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> * 1996: On April 15, a rupture, followed by an explosion and fire at 1829 EST, occurred on the TransCanada PipeLines Limited 864-millimetre (34-inch) natural gas pipeline, at Kilometre Post Mainline Valve 39-2 + 6.07 kilometres, 10 kilometres southwest of Winnipeg, near the town of [[St. Norbert, Manitoba]].<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/1996/p96h0012/p96h0012.asp</ref> * 1997: On April 30, a rupture occurred on the Westcoast Energy Inc. 219.1-millimetre (8-inch) outside diameter Monias pipeline at Mile Post 20, near [[Fort St. John, British Columbia]]. Approximately 85,000 cubic metres of sour natural gas was released and ignited.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/1997/p97h0024/p97h0024.asp</ref> * 1997: On December 2, a rupture occurred at an area of external corrosion on the TransCanada PipeLines Limited 914-millimetre outside diameter Line 100-3 at main line valve 5-3 + 15.049 kilometres, near [[Cabri, Saskatchewan]]. Approximately 3 252 × 10^3 cubic metres of natural gas was released as a result of the rupture. The gas ignited immediately, resulting in damage to the surrounding soil and vegetation. The main fire self-extinguished within 20 minutes of the line break.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/1997/p97h0063/p97h0063.asp</ref> * 1999: On May 20, Line 3 on the [[Enbridge]] Pipelines Inc. (Enbridge) pipeline system ruptured, releasing 3 123 cubic metres (m3) (20,600 barrels) of Cold Lake heavy crude oil, east of [[Regina, Saskatchewan]]. Approximately 3.6 hectares (ha) (8.8 acres) of farmland was affected by crude oil.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/1999/p99h0021/p99h0021.asp</ref> * 2000: On December 28, a release of natural gas resulted in an explosion that destroyed the electrical and services building, heavily damaged the compressor building, and damaged the remaining buildings at the East Hereford compressor station, approximately 80 km SE of [[Magog, Quebec]]. Before the occurrence, the station had been shut down due to an unintentional manual initiation of the station's emergency shutdown system. Following the emergency shutdown of the compressor station, a maintenance person was sent to the station to reinitiate the electric motor-driven compressor unit. During the day, after repeatedly trying to get the station into the ready state mode, to return the station to normal pipeline operations, an explosion occurred. The on-site maintenance person was seriously injured.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2000/p00h0061/p00h0061.asp</ref> * 2001: On January 17, a rupture occurred on the [[Enbridge]] Pipelines Inc. 864-millimetre outside diameter Line 3/4 at Mile Post 109.42, 0.8 kilometres downstream of the Hardisty pump station near [[Hardisty, Alberta]]. The rupture occurred in a permanent slough that was fed by an underground spring. Although the line was shut down at the control centre in Edmonton, Alberta, within minutes of the rupture, the exact location of the rupture was not found until after 13 hours. Approximately 3800 cubic metres of crude oil was released and contained within a 2.7-hectare section. As of 01 May 2001, 3760 cubic metres of crude oil had been recovered.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2001/p01h0004/p01h0004.asp</ref> * 2001: On September 29, a rupture occurred on the [[Enbridge]] Pipelines Inc. 508-millimetreoutside diameter Line 10 at Mile Post 1885.64, near [[Binbrook, Ontario]]. Line 10 transports crude oil from Westover, Ontario, to Buffalo, New York, United States. The rupture occurred in an agricultural field planted with soybeans. Within eight minutes of the rupture, the control centre operator in Edmonton, Alberta, shut the line down and began to sectionalize it. Remedial action response teams contained the spill to two general areas, a natural swale running perpendicular to the pipeline and the pipeline trench. Approximately 95 cubic metres of crude oil were released, affecting a 0.67-hectaresection of land.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2001/p01h0049/p01h0049.asp</ref> * 2002: On April 14, a rupture occurred on the 914-millimetre-diameter natural gas transmission pipeline, at a zone of near-neutral (low) pH stress corrosion cracking, on Line 100-3of the TransCanada PipeLines, at main-line valve 31-3 + 5.539 kilometres, approximately two kilometres from the village of [[Brookdale, Manitoba]]. Following the rupture, the sweet natural gas ignited. With the automatic closure of main-line valves upstream and downstream of the rupture site, the fire self-extinguished at 0230, on 15 April 2002. There were no injuries. As a precautionary measure, approximately 100 people were evacuated from the occurrence area within a four-kilometre radius, including the village of Brookdale, for a period of one day.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2002/p02h0017/p02h0017.asp</ref> * 2002: A refined product pipeline rupture near [[Saint-Clet, Quebec]], on Dec 7, from Trans Northern Pipelines Inc. 273.1 mm diameter mainline kilometer post 63.57, estimated 32 cubic meters of low sulphur diesel released to area and drainage systems. Transportation Safety Board Investigation Report Number P02H0052. http://www.tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2002/p02h0052/p02h0052.asp * 2003: A backhoe punctured a pipeline in [[Etobicoke, Ontario]] the [[2003 Etobicoke gas explosion|resulting explosion]] killed 7 people * 2005: On July 15, an employee of Terasen Pipelines (Trans Mountain) Inc. discovered crude oil on the pipeline right-of-way, on the north side of Ward Road, [[Abbotsford, British Columbia]]. Before the discovery, the company had been delivering crude oil out of the Sumas Tank Farm, when it received odour complaints from local residents. Approximately 210 cubic metres of crude oil was released into the surrounding area and made its way into Kilgard Creek. There were no injuries.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2005/p05h0044/p05h0044.asp</ref> * 2007: A crude oil pipeline owned and operated by [[Kinder Morgan Energy Partners]] was ruptured by an excavator digging a storm sewer trench in [[Burnaby]], [[British Columbia]] <ref>{{cite news| title=Cleanup continues on B.C. oil spill | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2007/07/24/bc-oilspill.html | work=CBC News}}</ref> * 2007: On 15 April, a rupture occurred on Enbridge Pipelines’ 864-millimetre outside diameter Line 3 at Mile Post 506.2217 downstream of the Glenavon pump station near [[Glenavon, Saskatchewan]]. The rupture occurred in a wetland area of farmland. Approximately 990 cubic meters of crude oil were released, of which approximately 912 cubic meters were recovered. There were no injuries. The cause was determined to be corrosion cracking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2007/p07h0014/p07h0014.asp|title=Pipeline Investigation Report P07H0014|first=Government of Canada, Transportation Safety Board of|last=Canada|website=www.tsb.gc.ca}}</ref> * 2007: On July 24, the 610-millimetre (24-inch) Westridge Dock Transfer Line, owned by Trans Mountain Pipeline L.P. and operated by Kinder Morgan Canada Inc., was struck and punctured by a contractor's excavator bucket while the contractor was excavating a trench for a new storm sewer line along Inlet Drive in [[Burnaby, British Columbia]]. When the pipeline was punctured, approximately 234 cubic metres of crude oil was released, approximately 210 cubic metres of which was recovered. Crude oil flowed into Burrard Inlet Bay via the Burnaby storm sewer system. Eleven houses were sprayed with crude oil; many other residential properties required restoration and approximately 250 residents voluntarily left their homes. There were no explosions, fires, or injuries resulting from this occurrence; however, emergency workers and two firefighters responding to the incident were sprayed with crude oil. Two members of the public were also sprayed.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2007/p07h0040/p07h0040.asp</ref> * 2009: A July 20 [[Alberta]] pipeline explosion & fire involved a [[TransCanada Corporation]] natural gas pipeline. The explosion, which sent 50 meter flames into the air, destroyed a two-hectare wooded area. The NEB said the delay in releasing the report was caused by an "administrative error", when an employee left without transferring the file over. The Peace River Mainline pipeline, built in 1968, had ruptured six times and leaked on 17 occasions until 2014. The line ruptured in 2009 due to corrosion.<ref>{{cite news| title=Pipeline rupture: Alberta resident unaware of 2009 blast | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/pipeline-rupture-alberta-resident-unaware-of-2009-blast-1.2525030 | work=CBC News}}</ref> * 2009: On 12 September 2009, [[TransCanada Corporation]]'s Gas Control received notification, from the Englehart Fire Department through its Emergency Notification Line, of an explosion and fire south of its Compressor Station 107, located near [[Swastika, Ontario]]. At the time of the occurrence, TransCanada was transporting sweet natural gas. Escaping gas from a pipeline rupture had ignited, resulting in the explosion. A large crater was created and two sections of pipe broke from the system, with one section being ejected approximately 150 metres from the rupture site. There were no injuries.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2009/p09h0074/p09h0074.asp</ref> * 2009: On 26 September 2009, [[TransCanada Corporation]]'s Line 100-1 ruptured, near [[Marten River, Ontario]]. At 1151, Gas Control at TransCanada's Calgary office became aware of this event when Main Line Valve 112-1, on the upstream side of Compressor Station 112, automatically shut off due to low pipeline pressure. At the time of the occurrence, TransCanada was transporting sweet natural gas. The escaping gas did not ignite. A large crater was created and pipe pieces were ejected from the failed pipeline section and spread around the occurrence site. There were no injuries.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2009/p09h0083/p09h0083.asp</ref> * 2009: On 29 September, an [[Enbridge]] crude oil pipeline, Line 2, leaked at Mile Post 474.7335, immediately downstream of the Odessa pump station near [[Odessa, Saskatchewan]]. The leak occurred at a crack within a shallow dent at the 6 o’clock position on the pipe. There were indications of gouging associated with the dent. The release occurred in a low lying, densely vegetated marsh. Approximately 175 cubic meters of crude oil was released, of which most was recovered. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2009/p09h0084/p09h0084.pdf |format=PDF |title=PIPELINE INVESTIGATION REPORT : P09H0084 : Crude Oil Pipeline Leak |website=Tsb.gc.ca |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2009: A refined product pipeline rupture near Farran's Point, Ontario on Ottawa Lateral, on October 5, from Trans Northern Pipelines Inc. system, unknown petroleum product, unknown quantity. Transportation Safety Board Report Number P09H0086. http://www.tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2009/p09h0086/p09h0086.asp{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * 2010: A refined product pipeline rupture at Bronte Creek in Oakville, Ontario, detected on March 11, from Trans Northern Pipeline Inc. system, estimated 23,770 gallons of gasoline released to creek, soil and ground water. Transportation Safety Board Report Number P10H0021. http://www.tsp.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2010/p10h0021/p10h0021.asp{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * 2011: On February 19, TransCanada PipeLines Limited's gas control operator received notification through its emergency notification line of a pipeline fire and explosion, near [[Beardmore, Ontario]]. At the time of the occurrence, TransCanada was transporting sweet natural gas. Escaping gas from a pipeline rupture had ignited, resulting in the explosion. A large crater was created and three pieces of pipe broke from the system, with pipe and other debris being ejected up to 100 m from the rupture site. Six residents near the site evacuated until the fire was extinguished. There were no injuries.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2011/p11h0011/p11h0011.asp</ref> * 2011: In April, a pipeline break northeast of [[Peace River, Alberta]], leaked 28,000 barrels of crude oil, Some wildlife was killed from the spill. The Energy Resources Conservation Board, an independent government agency that was dissolved in 2013, reprimanded the company, saying it had inadequate leak detection and failed to test its emergency response plan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/alta-oil-pipeline-leaked-28-000-barrels-1.1015125 |title=Alta. oil pipeline leaked 28,000 barrels - Edmonton - CBC News |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2011-05-03 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2012: In June, almost half a million liters of sour crude oil leaked into a creek that flows into the [[Red Deer River]], located about 100 kilometers north of [[Calgary]], near the community of [[Sundre]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/plains-midstream-criticized-for-pipeline-leak-into-red-deer-river-1.2560240 |title=Plains Midstream criticized for pipeline leak into Red Deer River - Edmonton - CBC News |publisher=Cbc.ca |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2012: On June 19, an [[Enbridge]] pipeline had a gasket failure, spilling about 1,400 barrels of crude oil, at a pumping station near [[Elk Point, Alberta]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/elk-point-pipeline-restarted-after-oil-spill-1.1240395 |title=Elk Point pipeline restarted after oil spill - Edmonton - CBC News |publisher=Cbc.ca |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2012: On June 23, an ignition and fire occurred in a valve-enclosure structure at Spectra Energy Transmission Compressor Station N4, located approximately 160 km northwest of [[Fort St. John, British Columbia]]. Two maintenance employees sustained burn injuries when sweet natural gas that had been leaking from a station valve ignited. The 2 employees were performing annual inspection work on motor-operated valves. The injured employees were air-lifted to the Fort St. John Hospital. One employee was released later that day, while the second employee was transferred to a burn unit in Vancouver.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2012/p12h0103/p12h0103.asp</ref> * 2012: On June 28, a pipeline rupture and ignition occurred on Westcoast Energy Inc.'s 406.4 mm (16-inch) Nig Creek pipeline, located about 40 km northwest of [[Buick, British Columbia]]. Approximately 25 minutes later, a pipeline rupture and ignition occurred on Bonavista Energy Corporation's 168.3 mm (6.625-inch) pipeline installed nearby in the same right-of-way. At the time of the ruptures, both pipelines had been shut down and contained pressurized sour gas. The fire spread to adjacent forested areas. A large crater was created, and one piece of the Nig Creek pipe was ejected along with other debris to approximately 20 m from the rupture site. There were no injuries and no evacuation was required.<ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2012/P12H0105/P12H0105.asp</ref> * 2013: In June, between 400,000 and 600,000 liters of produced water escaped from a pipeline, in addition to 5,000 liters of oil, near [[Little Buffalo, Alberta]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2013/06/24/pennwest-alberta-pipeline-oil-spill_n_3491465.html |title=Pennwest's Alberta Pipeline Spill Estimate Grows With Salt Water |publisher=Huffingtonpost.ca |date=2013-06-24 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2013: On October 17, a 36-inch natural gas pipeline ruptured southwest of [[Fort McMurray, Alberta]]. An estimated 16.5 million cubic meters of natural gas were released. The rupture did not result in a fire, there were no injuries and no evacuation was required. A fracture in a pipe elbow was the identified for the reason of the failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sys-con.com/node/3536027 |title=Thermal expansion on elbow joint led to October 2013 pipeline rupture near Fort McMurray, Alberta |publisher=news.sys-con.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2014: On January 25, a [[TransCanada Corporation]] gas transmission pipeline 762 mm (30-inch) Line 400-1 exploded and burned, near [[Otterburne, Manitoba]], causing a natural gas shortage in [[Manitoba]] and parts of the United States. Natural gas burned for approximately 12 hours. Five residences in the immediate vicinity were evacuated, and Provincial Highway 303 was closed until the fire was extinguished. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsreview.com/chico/transcanada-pipeline-explosion/content?oid=12685546 |title=Chico News & Review - TransCanada pipeline explosion - Earth Watch - Green - February 6, 2014 |publisher=Newsreview.com |date=2014-02-06 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref><ref>http://www.bst-tsb.gc.ca/eng/rapports-reports/pipeline/2014/p14h0011/p14h0011.asp</ref> * 2014: On April 2, a pipeline failed, and spilled 70,000 liters of oil and processed water, northwest of [[Slave Lake, Alberta]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/canadian-natural-resources-pipeline-leaks-near-slave-lake-1.2597036 |title=Canadian Natural Resources pipeline leaks near Slave Lake - Business - CBC News |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2014-04-03 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2014: In November, 60,000 liters of crude oil spilled into muskeg from a failed pipeline, in [[Red Earth Creek]] in northern [[Alberta]]. Officials were delayed in reaching the scene, due to poor weather at the time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/canadian-natural-resources-says-pipeline-spilled-60-000-litres-of-crude-1.2855461 |title=Canadian Natural Resources says pipeline spilled 60,000 litres of crude - Edmonton - CBC News |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2014-11-30 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2015: On March 1, a pipeline leak spilled about 17,000 barrel of condensate, in Northern [[Alberta]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Torres |first=Nicolas |url=http://petroglobalnews.com/2015/03/murphy-oil-reports-alberta-condensate-leak-now-17000-barrels/ |title=Murphy Oil reports Alberta condensate leak now 17,000 barrels |publisher=Petro Global News |date=2015-03-11 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2015: On May 5, a gas transmission pipeline failed approximately 36 kilometers southeast of [[Drumheller, Alberta]]. The incident resulted in an undetermined volume of sweet natural gas and associated hydrocarbon liquid being released onto agricultural land.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.gc.ca/web/article-en.do?mthd=advSrch&crtr.page=1&crtr.dpt1D=28&nid=971169 |title=Archived - National Energy Board Responding to Pipeline Incident in Central Alberta - Canada News Centre |publisher=News.gc.ca |date=2015-05-05 |accessdate=2016-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005155531/http://news.gc.ca/web/article-en.do?mthd=advSrch&crtr.page=1&crtr.dpt1D=28&nid=971169 |archivedate=2016-10-05 |df= }}</ref> * 2015: On July 15, a pipeline at a Long Lake oil sands facility in northern Alberta leaked about 31,500 barrels of oil emulsion. The spill covered approximately 16,000 square meters (4 acres) but was mostly contained within the pipeline's right of way.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/17/nexen-pipeline-spill-idUSL2N0ZW34220150717#4UJ6DlYq1BYrB1br.97 |title=UPDATE 1-Nexen pipeline leaks 31,500 bbls of emulsion at oil sands site |publisher=Reuters |date=2015-07-16 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2015: On August 14, a leak from a pipeline spilled about 100,000 liters of an oil, water, & gas emulsion on the Hay Lake First Nation, about 100 kilometers northwest of [[High Level, Alberta]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/business/alberta-energy-regulator-responds-to-100-000-litre-spill-in-northwestern-alberta-1.2524325 |title=Alberta Energy Regulator responds to 100,000-litre spill in northwestern Alberta | CTV News |publisher=Ctvnews.ca |date=2015-08-19 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2016: On July 21, a leaking Husky Energy pipeline spilled 225,000 liters of oil into the North Saskatchewan River, prompting a massive cleanup.<ref>http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatoon/judge-rules-husky-documents-sealed-pipeline-spill-1.4491223</ref> * 2017: On February 17, a total of 200,000 liters of oil condensate in Strathcona County, Alberta were released from line 2A, near Anthony Henday Drive and 92 Avenue,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.neb-one.gc.ca/bts/nws/whtnw/2017/2017-02-21-eng.html|title=NEB – Incident Update: Enbridge Line 2A Pipeline Incident|first=Government of Canada, National Energy|last=Board|website=www.neb-one.gc.ca}}</ref> after line was struck during 3rd party construction operations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.enbridge.com/media-center/media-statements/strathcona-county-incident-response|title=Edmonton Line 2A incident|publisher=}}</ref> * 2018: On January 7, a butane oil pipeline ruptured in [[St. John, New Brunswick]]. About 30 homes in the area were evacuated, as well as the SPCA Animal Rescue League Shelter.<ref>https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/oil-company-facing-scrutiny-after-butane-leak-in-saint-john-1.3764293</ref> * 2018: On May 27, a Trans Mountain pipeline leaked at the company’s Darfield station north of [[Kamloops, British Columbia]]. About 4,800 liters of crude were released.<ref>https://www.northislandgazette.com/news/trans-mountain-pipeline-spill-much-larger-than-b-c-government-first-reported/</ref> * 2018: On Oct 9, a 36 inch Enbridge natural gas pipeline exploded 13km north of Prince George, British Columbia. About 1 million BC customers and 750,000 US customers are affected. Natural gas customers are being asked to reduce use. <ref>https://globalnews.ca/news/4538358/prince-george-pipeline-explosion-not-criminal-in-nature-rcmp/</ref>
== China == * 2010: Dalian Pipeline disaster - The explosion of two petroleum pipelines and subsequent fire in the port of [[Dalian]], in northern China's Liaoning province on Saturday, on July 17, 2010, caused fatalities, damages and an ecological disaster, releasing 11,000 barrels of oil into the Yellow Sea, and covering up, according to different sources, from 50 to 430 km<sup>2</sup> of sea and coast lines. * 2013: a [[2013 Qingdao oil pipeline explosion|Sinopec Corp oil pipeline exploded]] in [[Huangdao]], Qingdao, Shandong Province, on November 22, 2013. 55 people were killed.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/news/pictures/slideshow?articleId=USRTX15OM8#a=1 Huangdao, Qingdao, Shandong Province disaster] accessdate=2013-11-22</ref>
== India == * 2014: On June 27, a pipeline blast in Southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh killed 22 people and injured 37. The pipeline was operated by Gas Authority of India Limited (GAIL) and a preliminary investigation revealed faulty operational procedures as a cause of fire.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/22-would-not-have-died-in-pipeline-blast-had-gail-installed-safety-features-as-it-had-promised-probe-report/|title=22 wouldn’t have died in pipeline blast had GAIL installed safety features: Probe report|date=2014-09-08|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2017-12-02|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-28052104|title=India gas pipeline blast kills 14|date=2014-06-27|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-02|language=en-GB}}</ref> * 2017: On April 29, a fire broke out in a GAIL operated gas pipeline caused by civil construction operations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/bangalore/fire-breaks-out-on-road-following-leak-in-gail-gas-pipeline/article18314848.ece|title=Fire breaks out on road following leak in GAIL gas pipeline|last=Reporter|first=Staff|date=2017-04-29|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-12-02|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> * 2017: On June 17, a farm near city of Jamnagar was flooded with oil. An oil pipeline operated by Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOCL) since 1999 was ruptured below 12 feet from the ground.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/ioc-pipeline-ruptured-near-jamnagar-oil-spreads-on-agricultural-land-4709205/|title=IOC pipeline ruptured near Jamnagar, oil spreads on agricultural land|date=2017-06-17|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2017-12-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Indonesia == * 2006: On Wednesday, October 18 a gas pipeline explosion killed at least seven people in East Java. The explosion was a consequence of land subsidence caused by volcanic mud eruptions, known as the Sidoarjo mud flow, that began erupting in late May and early June at the site of the Banjar-Panji 1 exploration well drilled by PT Lapindo Brantas.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/23/world/asia/23iht-blast.3642098.html|title=Indonesia gas blast linked to volcanic mud - Asia - Pacific - International Herald Tribune|last=Bonner|first=Raymond|date=2006-10-23|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-06-14|last2=Suhartono|first2=Muktita|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
== Kenya == * [[2011 Nairobi pipeline fire]] kills approximately 100 people and hospitalized 120.
== Malaysia == * 2014: PETRONAS gas pipeline explosion in the state of Sarawak, Malaysia ripped apart a portion of the RM3bil Sabah to Sarawak interstate gas pipeline between Lawas town and Long Sukang in the northernmost district of Sarawak at 2 a.m., resulting in the evacuation of nearby villagers.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/06/11/Blast-rips-SabahSarawak-gas-pipeline-No-one-hurt-in-2am-explosion-fire-is-out/ |title=Blast rips Sabah-Sarawak gas pipeline - Nation | The Star Online |publisher=Thestar.com.my |date=2014-06-11 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref>
==Mexico== * 1959 On July 1, a petroleum pipeline exploded, and burned for 7 hours in [[Coatzacoalcos]]. 12 people were killed, and 100 more injured.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4SBUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MzoNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2424,272599&dq=pipeline%20explosion&hl=en|title=St. Joseph News-Press - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9PhjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AuUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5618,7145313&dq=pipeline%20explosion&hl=en|title=The Sydney Morning Herald - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> * 1978 On November 1, a gas pipeline exploded and burned, killing 52 people in colonia Benito Juarez, [[Mexico]], and injuring 11 in a town of only 100 people. The failure created a crater 300 feet wide and 20 feet deep.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2209&dat=19781103&id=uhxSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JjUNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4978,558758|title=The Telegraph - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref><ref>"Mexican pipeline explosion all but wipes out tiny town," UPI, ''Morning News'' (Wilmington, Delaware), November 4, 1978, p. 2.</ref> * 2010 The [[2010 Puebla oil pipeline explosion|explosion on December 19, 2010]] of an oil pipeline at a [[Petroleos Mexicanos]] (Pemex) pumping station in [[San Martín Texmelucan de Labastida]] in central Mexico, killed at least 27 people and injured more than 50. The explosion is believed to have been caused by attempts to puncture the pipe to steal oil.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-1220-mexico-oil-explosion-20101220,0,5059943.story|title=27 die in oil pipeline explosion in Mexico|author=Ellingwood, Ken |publisher=The Los Angeles Times|date=December 20, 2010|accessdate=December 22, 2010}}</ref> * 2012 On September 18, 2012, twenty-two workers died when a gas leak from a [[Kinder Morgan]] pipeline at [[Reynosa]], [[Tamaulipas, Mexico]] sparked an explosion which became a fireball that overtook workers running for their lives, lead plaintiff Javier Alvarez del Castillo said. "They were engulfed in fire that burnt and singed every inch of skin from their head to their ankles, taking every bit of hair from their head, laying the plaintiffs 'skinless,' like skeletons bare to the bones, with in most cases only their footwear attached to the only portion of their body not reduced to skeleton." He blamed Kinder Morgan for not adding enough of the odorant methyl mercaptan to the gas. (Natural gas is odorless, so energy companies add the sulfur compound to make leaks smelly and therefore noticeable.) "A gas company may be liable if facts show that it fails to act reasonably after having notice of defects in the pipes through which gas flows," the ruling states, citing the Texas appellate court case [[Entex Energy|Entex]], a Division of NorAm Energy Corp. v. Gonzalez.<ref>Cameron Langford, “Kinder Morgan on Hook for Blast That Killed 22,” Courthouse News Service, July 15, 2016, in https://www.workerscompensation.com/news_read.php?id=24257&forgot=yes, accessed 2018-01-07.</ref> On July 13, 2016, a U.S. Federal Court ruled that only Kinder Morgan and not any of the other companies originally sued by plaintiffs’ groups should face the charges of gross negligence and negligence.<ref>"Kinder Morgan must defend fatal Mexican gas pipeline explosion court case," Hazardex, 2016.07.19, http://www.hazardexonthenet.net/article/121852/Kinder-Morgan-must-defend-fatal-Mexican-gas-pipeline-explosion-court-case.aspx, accessed 2018.01.07.</ref> The cause of the leak was a valve that apparently failed as workers performed routine testing, but gaps remain in what is known about the events that led up to the Reynosa explosion.<ref>Mark Stevenson, “Mexico blast a blow to Pemex's improving safety,” Deseret News, September 20, 2012, at https://www.deseretnews.com/article/765605627/Mexico-blast-a-blow-to-Pemexs-improving-safety.html, accessed 2018.01.07.</ref>
==Nigeria== * 1998: At Jesse in the [[Niger Delta]] in [[Nigeria]], a [[1998 Jesse pipeline explosion|petroleum pipeline exploded]] killing well over 500 villagers, some of whom were scavenging [[gasoline]]. The worst of several similar incidents in this country.<ref name="nation">{{cite web|url= http://www.thenationonlineng.com/dynamicpage.asp?id=51129|title= A chronology of pipeline fires in Nigeria|accessdate=2008-05-20 |website= Thenationonlineng.com|publisher=The Nation (Lagos), Friday, May 16, 2008}} {{dead link|date=March 2011}}</ref> (October 18, 1998) * 2000: Another pipeline explosion near the town of Jesse killed about 250 villagers.<ref name="nation"/> (July 10, 2000) * 2000: At least 100 villagers died when a ruptured pipeline exploded in [[Warri]].<ref name="nation"/> (July 16, 2000) * 2000: A leaking pipeline caught fire near the fishing village of [[Ebute]] near [[Lagos]], killing at least 60 people.<ref name="nation"/> (November 30, 2000) * 2003: A pipeline punctured by thieves exploded and killed 125 villagers near [[Umuahia]], [[Abia State]].<ref name="nation"/> (June 19, 2003) * 2004: A pipeline punctured by thieves exploded and killed dozens of people in [[Lagos State]].<ref name="nation"/> (September 17, 2004) * 2006: An oil pipeline punctured by thieves exploded and killed 150 people at the [[2006 Atlas Creek pipeline explosion|Atlas Creek Island]] in Lagos State.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/4768159.stm Probe ordered after Nigeria blast], May 13, 2006, BBC News</ref> (May 12, 2006) * 2006: A [[2006 Abule Egba pipeline explosion|vandalised oil pipeline exploded]] in Lagos. Up to 500 people may have been killed.<ref>[http://uk.news.yahoo.com/26122006/325/500-killed-lagos-fuel-blast.html Up to 500 killed in Lagos fuel blast] {{dead link|date=March 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, December 26, 2006, Yahoo News</ref> (December 26, 2006) * 2008: The [[2008 Ijegun pipeline explosion]] (May 16) * 2016: Vandalism at the Akulagba pipeline in Warri South - West Local Government Area of Delta State (January 22, 2016)<ref>{{cite news|last1=Niyi|title=Itsekiri Group Condemns Attacks On Emami Over Support To FG On Tracking Down Pipeline Vandals|url=http://www.informationng.com/2016/01/itsekiri-group-condemns-attacks-on-emami-over-support-to-fg-on-tracking-down-pipeline-vandals.html|accessdate=2 March 2017|work=Information Nigeria|date=January 22, 2016}}</ref> * 2016: The Fire explosion at Arepo and other coastal communities Pipeline in Ogun State (July 29, 2016)<ref>{{cite news|last1=Daniel|first1=Ayodele|title=Military Launches Attack On Militants’ Base In Ogun Coastal Communities|url=http://www.informationng.com/2016/07/military-launches-attack-on-militants-base-in-ogun-coastal-communities.html|accessdate=2 March 2017|work=Information Nigeria|date=July 29, 2016}}</ref>
==Russia==
* June 1982 [[Trans-Siberian Pipeline]], three kilotons,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/02/opinion/the-farewell-dossier.html|title=The Farewell Dossier|author=|date=2 February 2004|work=The New York Times|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> via [[Farewell Dossier]] ([[Siberian pipeline sabotage]]) * 1989 The [[Ufa train disaster]]: Sparks from two passing trains caused gas leaking from an [[Liquified petroleum gas|LPG]] pipeline near [[Ufa]], [[Russia]] to explode. Workers with the pipeline noticed pressure dropping in the line, but they increased pressure instead of searching for a leak. Trees up to 4 kilometers away were felled by the blast, and 2 locomotives and 38 passenger cars on the trains were derailed. Up to 645 people were reported killed on June 4, 1989.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9M5dAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UV0NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1104,1780217&dq=propane%20pipeline%20leak&hl=en|title=Observer-Reporter - Google News Archive Search|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> * 2018 On January 18, a monstrous blaze resembling a wall of fire has engulfed a village in Russia’s southern Saratov region after an oil transit pipeline sprung a leak. The flames raged for hours, devastating several houses. Some 2,000 cubic meters of oil spilled over to the adjacent territory and flooded several streets of the neighboring Krasnoarmeiskoe village in Russia’s Volga region. The oil then caught fire. No casualties were reported, according to Russian media, citing “preliminary reports” of the emergency services.<ref>https://www.rt.com/news/416339-russia-pipeline-village-blaze/</ref>
== Taiwan ==
* 2014: On the night of July 31, [[2014 Kaohsiung gas explosions|a string of explosions]] originating in buried gas pipes occurred in the city of [[Kaohsiung]]. Leaking gas, suspected to be propylene, filled the storm drains along several major thoroughfares and the resulting explosions turned several kilometers of road surface into deep trenches, sending vehicles, people and debris high into the air and igniting fires over a large area. At least 30 people were killed and over 300 injured.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Gladys Tsai|author2=Ralph Jennings |url=https://news.yahoo.com/taiwan-explosions-probe-focuses-petrochem-firm-084259627.html |title=Taiwan explosions probe focuses on petrochem firm |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date=2014-08-02 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=直播✦活動 |url=http://www.setnews.net/News.aspx?PageGroupID=1&NewsID=33335&PageType=1 |title=高雄驚傳嚴重氣爆意外 死傷人數攀升至28人、286傷 | 首頁 | 三立新聞網 SETN.COM |publisher=Setnews.net |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://focustaiwan.tw/news/aeco/201408060012.aspx |title=Economics minister urges Kaohsiung to offer new routes for gas pipes | Economics | FOCUS TAIWAN - CNA ENGLISH NEWS |publisher=Focustaiwan.tw |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref>
==United States== {{Main|List of pipeline accidents in the United States}}
From 1994 through 2013, the U.S. had 745 serious incidents with gas '''distribution''', causing 278 fatalities and 1059 injuries, with $110,658,083 in property damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/safety/serpsi.html?nocache=5339#_ngdistrib |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Serious Pipeline Incidents |publisher=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref>
From 1994 through 2013, there were an additional 110 serious incidents with gas '''transmission''', resulting in 41 fatalities, 195 injuries, and $448,900,333 in property damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/safety/serpsi.html?nocache=5339#_ngtrans |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Serious Pipeline Incidents |publisher=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref>
From 1994 through 2013, there were an additional 941 serious incidents with gas '''all system type''', resulting in 363 fatalities, 1392 injuries, and $823,970,000 in property damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hip.phmsa.dot.gov/analyticsSOAP/saw.dll?Portalpages |title=Oracle Business Intelligence |publisher=Hip.phmsa.dot.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref>
A recent Wall Street Journal review found that there were 1,400 pipeline spills and accidents in the U.S. 2010–2013. According to the Journal review, four in every five pipeline accidents are discovered by local residents, not the companies that own the pipelines.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sider |first=Alison |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303754404579310920956322040?mg=reno64-wsj&url=http%3A%2F%2Fonline.wsj.com%2Farticle%2FSB10001424052702303754404579310920956322040.html |title=Monitors Often Miss Oil Pipeline Leaks - WSJ |website=Online.wsj.com |date=2014-01-20 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/1/25/transcanada-naturalgaspipelineexpodesnearwinnipeg.html |title=TransCanada natural gas pipeline explodes near Winnipeg | Al Jazeera America |website=America.aljazeera.com |date=2014-01-25 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref>
'''Explosion details'''
* 1965 (March 4) A 32-inch gas transmission pipeline, north of Natchitoches, Louisiana, belonging to the Tennessee Gas Pipeline exploded and burned from Stress corrosion cracking (SCC) on March 4, killing 17 people. At least 9 others were injured, and 7 homes 450 feet from the rupture were destroyed. The same pipeline had also had an explosion on May 9, 1955, just 930 feet (280 m) from the 1965 failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gendisasters.com/louisiana/53/natchitoches-la-gas-pipeline-explosion-mar-1965|title=Natchitoches, LA Gas Pipeline Explosion, Mar 1965 - GenDisasters ... Genealogy in Tragedy, Disasters, Fires, Floods|website=www.gendisasters.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420101007H/420101007H_CAO_12032010.pdf |title=Letter to Bill Cope |last= |first= |date=December 3, 2010 |website=primis.phmsa.dot.gov |publisher=US Dept of Transportation}}</ref> * 1999 (June 10) An Olympic gasoline pipeline ruptured near Bellingham, Washington, resulting in 3 deaths: a fly fisherman and two 10-year-old boys. The cause was a series of errors and malfunctions in relief systems and process control computer systems in the Olympic Pipeline system, resulting in 277,000 gallons of gasoline spilled to Whatcom Creek. The fire burned for five days.<ref>[[Olympic Pipeline explosion]]</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Kira Millage |url=http://www.bellinghamherald.com/2009/06/07/938966/timeline-of-bellingham-pipeline.html |title=Timeline of Bellingham pipeline explosion |publisher=[[Bellingham Herald]] |date=2009-06-07 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2000 (19 August) A 30-inch El Paso Energy natural gas pipeline exploded, killing twelve people in southeast New Mexico. They were camping under a bridge which carried the pipeline across the Pecos River. The explosion occurred underground on the east side of the river 200 to 300 yards from the campers around 5:30 a.m.. The explosion left a crater 86 feet long, 46 feet wide and 20 feet deep. The fireball was visible 20 miles north in Carlsbad, N.M. The pipeline was installed in 1950.<ref>{{cite web|title="Natural Gas Pipeline Rupture and Fire Near Carlsbad, New Mexico, August 19, 2000." Pipeline Accident Report NTSB/PAR-03/01|date=February 11, 2003|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAR0301.pdf|format=PDF|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2004 (May 24) A pinhole-sized leak caused by wear unleashed thousands of gallons of gasoline that fueled the BP / Olympic pipeline fire and explosion near the Westfield Shoppingtown Southcenter in Renton, Washington. The blaze sent three firefighters to the hospital, and a mile-square area, which included a nearby fire station, was cordoned off. The leak occurred in a half-inch-wide tube of stainless steel that Olympic operators use to extract fuel samples from the system's 16-inch-wide main line. A metal electrical conduit had rubbed against the stainless steel sampling tube to open the pinhole leak.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/Wear-caused-gas-leak-in-Olympic-pipeline-1145599.php |title=Wear caused gas leak in Olympic pipeline |website=Seattlepi.com |date=2004-05-24 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2010 (September 9) The [[San Bruno pipeline explosion]]: At 6:11 PM, a PG&E 30-inch natural gas line exploded in San Bruno, California, killing 8. Eyewitnesses reported the initial blast "had a wall of fire more than 1,000 feet high".<ref>San Bruno Explosion: Photos Of The Fire's Aftermath Paint A Bigger Picture. Huffingtonpost.com. Retrieved on November 8, 2011</ref> * 2010 (July 25) Crude oil pipeline ruptures near Marshall, Michigan, spilling over 840,000 gallons of oil into the Kalamazoo River <ref>{{cite news|author=Emmanuel, Adeshina|title="Preventable Errors Led to Pipeline Spill, Inquiry Finds"|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 July 2012|url=http://green.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/10/preventable-errors-led-to-pipeline-spill-inquiry-finds/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0>|accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cooper |first=Aaron |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/10/us/michigan-oil-spill-ntsb-findings/index.html?iref=allsearch |title=Feds: Operator knew of pipeline problems years before Michigan oil spill |website=CNN.com |date=2012-07-11 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2012 (12 December) a 20-inch transmission line owned by NiSource Inc., parent of Columbia Gas, exploded, leveling 4 houses, between Sissonville and Pocatalico in Kanawha County, West Virginia (WV). When it blew, nobody at pipeline operator, Columbia Gas Transmission knew it. An 800' section of I-77 was obliterated.<ref name="npr.org">{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2012/12/13/167169109/no-alarm-sounded-when-the-west-virginia-pipeline-exploded |title=No Alarm Sounded When The West Virginia Pipeline Exploded : The Two-Way |publisher=NPR |date=2012-12-13 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wvmetronews.com/2013/06/07/ntsb-releases-details-about-sissonville-pipeline-explosion-investigation/ |title=WV MetroNews – NTSB releases details about Sissonville pipeline explosion investigation |publisher=Wvmetronews.com |date=2012-12-11 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> "The fire melted the interstate and it looked like lava, just boiling." Later the West Virginia Public Service Commission released several pages of violations by Columbia Gas.<ref>{{cite web|author=Edward Mills |url=http://wvmetronews.com/2013/12/11/remembering-the-sissonville-pipeline-explosion/ |title=WV MetroNews – Remembering the Sissonville pipeline explosion |website=Wvmetronews.com |date=2013-12-11 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> Forty families were "impacted" by the explosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wowktv.com/story/23266781/eight-settle-claims-over-gas-pipeline-explosion |title=Eight settle claims over gas pipeline explosion - WOWK 13 Charleston, Huntington WV News, Weather, Sports |website=Wowktv.com |date=2016-09-29 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/11/us-usa-blast-westvirginia-idUSBRE8BA16B20121211 |title=Nisource gas pipeline explodes near Charleston, West Virginia |publisher=Reuters |date=2012-12-11 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> The investigation cited "external corrosion" as the cause of the blast.<ref>{{cite book|last1=National Transportation Safety Board|title=Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation Pipeline Rupture Sissonville, West Virginia December 11, 2012 Accident Report|date=February 19, 2014|publisher=National Transportation Safety Board|pages=50|url=https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAR1401.pdf|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="npr.org"/><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/12/11/west-virginia-gas-explosion/1761757/ |title=W.Va. gas explosion burns homes, shuts I-77 |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=2012-12-11 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2013 (29 March) ExxonMobil pipeline carrying Canadian Wabasca heavy crude from the Athabasca oil sands ruptured in Mayflower, Arkansas, about 25 miles northwest of Little Rock. Approximately 12,000 barrels (1,900 m3) of oil mixed with water had been recovered by March 31. Twenty-two homes were evacuated.[1] The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) classified the leak as a major spill. A reported 5,000−7,000 barrels of crude were released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Business_News/Energy-Resources/2013/04/10/Exxon-faces-deadline-for-oil-spill/UPI-56081365598614/ |title=Exxon faces Wednesday deadline for Ark. oil spill documents |publisher=UPI.com |date=2013-04-10 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2013 (20 August) Explosion of a natural gas pipeline near [[Kiowa, Oklahoma|Kiowa]] southwest of Oklahoma City <ref>{{cite web|last=Shea |first=Paul |url=http://www.valuewalk.com/2013/08/nat-gas-pipeline-explosion-reported-in-oklahoma/ |title=Nat Gas Pipeline Explosion Reported In Oklahoma |publisher=Valuewalk.com|date=2013-08-20 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2013 (8 October) Explosion of a natural gas pipeline near [[Rosston, Oklahoma]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/09/oklahoma-pipeline-explosion_n_4068377.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Pipeline Explodes In Oklahoma | date=October 9, 2013 | first=Jade | last=Walker}}</ref> * 2014 (Jan 25) A Trans Canada pipeline about 15 miles south of Winnipeg ruptured and exploded. The incident prompted the precautionary closure of two nearby pipelines. The pipelines supply the main source of natural gas to more than 100,000 Xcel Energy customers in eastern North Dakota, northwestern Minnesota and western Wisconsin.<ref name="twincities.com">{{cite web|author=Pioneer Press |url=http://www.twincities.com/localnews/ci_25838227/gas-pipeline-explodes-nortwestern-minnesota-none-hurt |title=Northwestern Minnesota gas pipeline explosion: ‘It was just hell on earth’ – Twin Cities |publisher=Twincities.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> The explosion happened near Otterburne, Manitoba, about 15 miles south of the provincial capital, Winnipeg. The area was evacuated as a precaution. No injuries were reported but the fire burned for more than 12 hours.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/1/25/transcanada-naturalgaspipelineexpodesnearwinnipeg.html |title=TransCanada natural gas pipeline explodes near Winnipeg | Al Jazeera America |publisher=America.aljazeera.com |date=2014-01-25 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2014 (Feb) In Knifely, Adair County, Kentucky, a Columbia Gulf gas pipeline exploded at 1 a.m. flattening homes, burning barns, and causing one casualty. The 30-inch natural gas pipeline was about 100 feet from Highway 76 and buried 30 feet underground. When it exploded, large rocks and sections of pipeline flew into the air, leaving a 60-foot crater. Columbia Gulf, part of NiSource’s Columbia Pipeline Group, owns and operates more than 15,700 miles of natural gas pipelines, one of the largest underground storage systems in North America. The pipeline that exploded was carrying natural gas from the Gulf of Mexico to New York.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2014/02/13/3287531/kentucky-natural-gas-explosion/ |title=Natural Gas Pipeline Explosion Levels Homes In Kentucky Town |publisher=Thinkprogress.org |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2014 (Feb 11) A Hiland gas pipeline exploded about six miles south of Tioga, North Dakota. Hiland was "blowing" hydrates, ice-like solids formed from a mixture of water and gas that can block pipeline flow, out of the pipeline.<ref>{{cite web|author=JESSICA HOLDMAN |url=http://bismarcktribune.com/bakken/natural-gas-explosion-reported-near-tioga/article_d4f90b48-9333-11e3-a757-0019bb2963f4.html |title=Natural gas explosion reported near Tioga | Bakken News |website=bismarcktribune.com |date=2014-02-11 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2014 (Mar 14) A Northern Natural Gas Company pipeline erupted near the intersection of county roads 20 and O, about six miles north of Fremont, Nebraska. A company spokesman said, "In the summer you can tell if you've got a gas leak by vegetation, sometimes it dies in the ground."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ketv.com/news/reports-of-natural-gas-line-explosion-north-of-fremont/24975672#ixzz34hwP9oIw |title=No injuries reported in Neb. gas pipeline blast | Local News - KETV Home |publisher=Ketv.com |date=2014-03-14 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> * 2014 (May 26) A Viking gas pipeline explosion near Warren, Minnesota was "hell on earth," shaking the ground and shooting a fireball over 100 feet in the air. Roads within a two-mile radius were blocked off. Authorities suspected natural causes because there was still frost in the ground and the soil was wet.<ref name="twincities.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/260672051.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529205938/http://www.startribune.com/local/260672051.html |archivedate=2014-05-29 |df= }}</ref> * 2017 (November 16) TransCanada's [[Keystone Pipeline]] leaked 210,000 gallons (5,000 barrels) of [[crude oil]] in [[Marshall County, South Dakota|Marshall County]] in northeastern South Dakota. Officials don't believe the leak affected any surface water bodies or threatened any drinking water systems.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-keystone-pipeline-leak-20171116-story.html|title=Keystone pipeline leaks 210K gallons of oil in South Dakota|last=Press|first=Associated|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2017-11-17|language=en-US}}</ref> *2018 (September 13) Suspected over-pressurization of natural gas pipes by Columbia Gas caused multiple explosions and fires in 3 towns in Massachusetts (Andover, Lawrence, and North Andover), leaving 1 dead. <ref><nowiki> {{</nowiki>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_gas_explosions<nowiki>}}</nowiki></ref>
==See also== *[[List of oil spills]] *[[Natural gas pipeline system in United States]] **[[Pigging]] *[[Hydrostatic test]] * [[Varanus Island]], [[Western Australia]] **[[2008 Western Australian gas crisis]] *Palaceknowe Gas Pipeline Failure, Moffat, [[Beattock]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dumgal.gov.uk/CHttpHandler.ashx?id%3D3067%26p%3D0 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121209035221/http://www.dumgal.gov.uk/CHttpHandler.ashx?id=3067&p=0 |archivedate=2012-12-09 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CaseStatus_opid_0.html?nocache=3500 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Summary of Enforcement Case Status |website=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-10-04}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/portal/site/PHMSA/menuitem.ebdc7a8a7e39f2e55cf2031050248a0c/vgnextoid=fdd2dfa122a1d110VgnVCM1000009ed07898RCRD&vgnextchannel=3430fb649a2dc110VgnVCM1000009ed07898RCRD&vgnextfmt=print |title=PHMSA - Home |website=Phmsa.dot.gov |date=2012-12-13 |accessdate=2016-10-04}} *{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2014/06/11/Blast-rips-SabahSarawak-gas-pipeline-No-one-hurt-in-2am-explosion-fire-is-out/ |title=Blast rips Sabah-Sarawak gas pipeline - Nation | The Star Online |website=Thestar.com.my |date=2014-06-11 |accessdate=2016-10-04}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pipeline Accidents}} [[Category:Pipeline accidents| ]] [[Category:Pollution-related lists]]

page.title: List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2009

revision.comment: added [[Category:2009 disasters in the United States]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}}
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2009'''. It is one of several [[list of pipeline accidents in the United States|lists of U.S. pipeline accidents]]. See also [[list of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States]]. {{expand list|date=April 2013}} __NOTOC__ <!--begin temporary compact toc--> <!-- something nicer-looking and more navigable should be done here; this is a temporary TOC to ease navigation -->
<!-- | bgcolor=#dddddd align=center colspan=11 | See also – [[#References|References]] --> <!--end compact toc-->
== Incidents ==
This is not a complete list of all pipeline accidents. '''For natural gas alone''', the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), a United States Department of Transportation agency, has collected data on more than 3,200 accidents deemed serious or significant since 1987.
A "significant incident" results in any of the following consequences: * fatality or injury requiring in-patient hospitalization * $50,000 or more in total costs, measured in 1984 dollars * liquid releases of five or more barrels (42 US gal/barrel) * releases resulting in an unintentional fire or explosion
PHMSA and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) post incident data and results of investigations into accidents involving pipelines that carry a variety of products, including natural gas, oil, diesel fuel, gasoline, kerosene, jet fuel, carbon dioxide, and other substances. Occasionally pipelines are repurposed to carry different products.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA's Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10. PHMSA Corrective Action Orders are at https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CAO_opid_0.html. PHMSA Pipeline Failure Investigation Reports are at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/safety-reports/pipeline-failure-investigation-reports. NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports are at https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx.</ref>
* On January 4, 2009, a 6.625-inch storage well line operated by [[Columbia Gas Transmission]] Company in Elk View (near Charleston), Kanawha County, West Virginia, ruptured due to internal corrosion pitting, complicated by low impact toughness of the pipe material, causing $29,011 in damage.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/sites/phmsa.dot.gov/files/docs/CGT_GT_WV_20090104.pdf|title=US DoT report |date=August 2, 2011 |website=phmsa.dot.gov |publisher=US DoT}}</ref> * On January 15, an accidental massive gas release at Pump Station 1 of the trans-Alaskan pipeline by [[Alyeska Pipeline Service Company]] threatened the site at the time. The company that runs the pipeline acknowledges a fire or explosion, had the gas ignited, could have imperiled the station's 60-plus workers and caused "an extended shutdown" of oil fields. There was no ignition or explosion. The incident occurred as BP workers used a cleaning device called a pig to swab oil out of an old pipeline the company was preparing to decommission. The 34-inch pipe was among major Prudhoe trunk lines found in 2006 to be ravaged with corrosion, due to BP's admitted lack of proper maintenance. A large volume of gas then bypassed the pig somehow, and rushed to Pump Station 1, a key asset through which every drop of oil coming off the North Slope must pass.<ref>{{cite web|first=Wesley |last=Loy |url=http://www.adn.com/2009/02/06/682090/inquiry-launched-after-pump-station.html |title=Inquiry launched after pump station accident |publisher=ADN.com |date=February 6, 2009 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927144559/http://www.adn.com/2009/02/06/682090/inquiry-launched-after-pump-station.html |archivedate=September 27, 2013}}</ref> * On February 11, a gas pipeline exploded and burned near a natural gas treatment plant, near [[Carthage, Texas]]. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2009/02/11/explosion-dcp-texas-idUKN1135208520090211 |agency=Reuters |title=UPDATE 1-Explosion near DCP Midstream's Texas natgas plant |date=February 11, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028005229/http://uk.reuters.com/article/2009/02/11/explosion-dcp-texas-idUKN1135208520090211 |archivedate=October 28, 2013 }}</ref> * At approximately 5 p.m. on February 18, a rupture of pipeline near the pump station and terminal located in [[Cygnet, Ohio]], owned by Philadelphia-based [[Sunoco]], resulted in one of the largest oil spills in Wood County history.<ref>{{cite web|title=Press release by Sunoco Logistics |url=http://www.wtol.com/story/9873737/press-release-by-sunoco-logistics |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170219083344/http://www.wtol.com/story/9873737/press-release-by-sunoco-logistics |archivedate=February 19, 2017 }}</ref> Upon learning of the release, the company immediately shut down the pipeline, stopped operations at the pump station and terminal, notified the appropriate authorities, and began an emergency response. As of 11:05 a.m. ET on February 19, the release had been stopped from the pipe. The damaged pipeline, which was operating at the time, released crude oil into a farm field. Eventually, about 19,000 gallons of the 52,500 gallons released were recovered. Some of the crude oil did contaminate a local creek. There were no fatalities, or injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toledoblade.com/article/20100730/NEWS16/7290358 |title=Ohio, Michigan score among highest for states with oil spills |publisher=Toledoblade.com |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Pipeline Failure Investigation Report – 2-18-2009 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/Mid_Valley_HL_OH_2009-02-18_508.pdf |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201174551/http://phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/Mid_Valley_HL_OH_2009-02-18_508.pdf |archivedate=February 1, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="dot.gov1">{{cite web|url=https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_12470.html?nocache=4784#_Incidents_tab_3|title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information|website=primis.phmsa.dot.gov}}</ref> * On February 19, leaking gas was detected near homes, in [[Somerset, Massachusetts]]. Evacuations followed, but one resident who did not respond to knocking on doors was killed, when the gas exploded. Prior excavation damage to a gas main was the cause.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/02/21/before_explosion_gas_crew_waved_off_help/|title=Before explosion, gas crew waved off help|first1=Brian|last1=Ballou|first2=David|last2=Abel|first3=Milton J.|last3=Valencia|date=February 21, 2009|publisher=|via=The Boston Globe}}</ref> * On May 4, [[Kinder Morgan]]'s [[Florida Gas Transmission]] pipeline burst near Palm City and Hobe City, Florida (near [[Port Salerno, Florida]]). The explosion ejected 106 feet of buried pipe weighing about 5,000 pounds out of the ground and onto the right-of-way between Interstate 95 and the Florida Turnpike (SR-91). The rupture was near a high school that was within the 366-foot potential impact radius. Two people were injured when their car ran off the road, and a Sheriff's deputy walked through a dense cloud and inhaled natural gas. The escaping gas did not ignite. The pipe was manufactured in 1959. The leak caused $596,218 in property damage. FGT was cited for safety violations: failing to identify a high-consequence area, failing to test operators for alcohol and drugs, and failing to have prompt emergency response; PHMSA assessed a $95,000 fine.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 2-2009-1002H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220091002H/220091002H_CAO_05072009.pdf?nocache=4283 |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304080826/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220091002H/220091002H_CAO_05072009.pdf?nocache=4283 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref> * On May 5, a natural gas pipeline exploded and caught on fire, near [[Rockville, Indiana]] in Parke County, about {{convert|24|mi|km}} north of [[Terre Haute, Indiana]]. The cause of this failure was determined to be external corrosion. Additional work performed as a result of this order provided significant indications of external corrosion in various sections of this line. Pictures have been released around the area showing the damage caused. 52 people were evacuated in a one-mile (1.6 km) area of the explosion. No injuries reported.<ref name="dot3">{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2014-10088 |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320141008S/320141008S_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20Safety%20Order_12242014.pdf |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115105300/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320141008S/320141008S_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20Safety%20Order_12242014.pdf |archivedate=January 15, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2009-1009H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320091009H/320091009H_CAO_05132009.pdf?nocache=6515 |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304070206/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320091009H/320091009H_CAO_05132009.pdf?nocache=6515 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref> * On May 21, an [[Enbridge]] pipeline pig sending trap in [[Superior, Wisconsin]] leaked from operator error, spilling about 6500 gallons of crude oil. 700 cubic yards of contaminated soil had to be removed.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF 3-2012-5018 |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320125018/320125018_NOPV%20PCP_08272012.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161224081623/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320125018/320125018_NOPV%20PCP_08272012.pdf |archivedate=December 24, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/272967 |title=May 21, 2009 – ProPublica |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115859/http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/272967 |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On July 15, an explosion occurred at Kinder Morgan's Midcontinent Express pipeline natural gas metering station that was under construction, while it was being pressure tested with nitrogen, in [[Smith County, Mississippi]]. One worker was killed, and two others injured. There was no fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kltv.com/Global/story.asp?s=10741392&clienttype=printable |title=Pipeline accident investigation could take months – KLTV.com-Tyler, Longview, Jacksonville, Texas | ETX News |publisher=Kltv.com |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027225750/http://www.kltv.com/Global/story.asp?s=10741392&clienttype=printable |archivedate=October 27, 2013 }}</ref> The workers were "literally right on top" of the explosion; their injuries were caused by pressure, not heat. One worker was injured when part of the pipe fell on him. The explosion snapped and bent a pipeline connected to a massive separator unit which was slung several yards.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pipeline explodes,killed 1 injured 3 |url=https://www.industrialprojectsreport.com/forum/showthread.php?8590-Pipeline-explodes-killed-1-injured-3 |website=www.industrialprojectsreport.com |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304024817/https://www.industrialprojectsreport.com/forum/showthread.php?8590-Pipeline-explodes-killed-1-injured-3 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref> * On August 10, operators of a [[Belle Fourche]] pipeline incorrectly operated the line, causing it to fail, near [[Edgerton, Wyoming]]. About 30,000 gallons of crude oil were spill, with about 1,200 gallons being lost.<ref name="dot4">{{cite web|title=UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION Washington, D.C. 20549 FORM 10-Q |url=https://www.magellanlp.com/uploadedFiles/Investors/Financials/2006/MMP%20-%203q06%2010q%20-%20Final%20Donnelley%20Draft.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216093213/http://magellanlp.com/uploadedFiles/Investors/Financials/2006/MMP%20-%203q06%2010q%20-%20Final%20Donnelley%20Draft.pdf |archivedate=December 16, 2010 }}</ref> * On August 17, a pipeline was found leaking by an aerial patrol in Atoka County, Oklahoma. {{convert|50|oilbbl|m3}} of diesel fuel were estimated to have been released as a result of this accident, and none of it was recovered.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration – November 2, 2010 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/Explorer_HL_OK_2009-08-17_508.pdf |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127220057/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/Explorer_HL_OK_2009-08-17_508.pdf |archivedate=November 27, 2016 }}</ref> * On October 7, a leaking pipeline carrying jet fuel was accidentally ignited by a pipeline repair crew in [[Upton County, Texas]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Upton County Gas Line Fire Caused by Leak |url=http://www.texas-fire.com/2009/10/08/upton-county-gas-line-fire-caused-by-leak/ |accessdate=October 30, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315222201/http://www.texas-fire.com/2009/10/upton-county-gas-line-fire-caused-by-leak/ |archivedate=March 15, 2012}}</ref> * On October 28, [[Kinder Morgan]]'s Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America above-ground storage tank north of St. Elmo, [[Illinois]] caught fire, injuring two workers. Welding caused the tank to ignite resulting in several explosions. Two workers were taken to the hospital.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fire rocks plant north of St. Elmo|url=http://www.effinghamdailynews.com/news/local_news/fire-rocks-plant-north-of-st-elmo/article_944c2536-0733-5549-ba26-baacb0e805a2.html|website=Effingham Daily News|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref> * On November 5, two people were hurt when an [[El Paso Natural Gas]] pipeline exploded in the Texas Panhandle near [[Bushland, Texas]]. The explosion left a hole about 30 yards by 20 yards and close to {{convert|15|ft|m}} deep. The orange inferno rose about 700 feet in the air; the blast incinerated the home of the Jose Torres family, injuring his wife Agnieszka and daughter Franczeska. About 200 residents in the area were evacuated. Bushland is in Potter County, about {{convert|15|mi|km}} west of Amarillo. The failure was in an abandoned tap, but the exact failure reason remains unknown. The explosion cause $436,136 in property damage.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 4-2009-1021H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420091021H/420091021H_CAO_11102009.pdf?nocache=4008 |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304070338/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420091021H/420091021H_CAO_11102009.pdf?nocache=4008 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.firefightingnews.com/articlePSO-US.cfm?articleID=72461 |title=Home Destroyed In Texas Gas Line Blast |publisher=Firefightingnews.com |date=November 5, 2009 |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027202708/http://www.firefightingnews.com/articlePSO-US.cfm?articleID=72461 |archivedate=October 27, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Kevin Welch |author2=JC Cortez |title=Bushland gas release reminds residents of 2009 explosion |publisher=Amarillo Globe-News |url=http://amarillo.com/news/local-news/2014-06-25/bushland-neighborhood-evacuated-after-gas-pipeline-rupture |accessdate=January 19, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128012018/http://amarillo.com/news/local-news/2014-06-25/bushland-neighborhood-evacuated-after-gas-pipeline-rupture |archivedate=January 28, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 4-2009-1021H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420091021H/420091021H_Closure_04132011.pdf |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170301004014/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/420091021H/420091021H_Closure_04132011.pdf |archivedate=March 1, 2017 }}</ref> * On November 14, a fire at a gas compressor station near [[Cameron, West Virginia]] slightly burned one employee, and caused $5.6 million of damage to the facility.<ref>{{cite web|title=Columbia Gas Transmission – Adaline Compressor Station Fire Failure Date 11/14/2009 |url=http://phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Pipeline/Columbia_GasTrans_GT_WV_2009-11-14.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002040127/http://phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Pipeline/Columbia_GasTrans_GT_WV_2009-11-14.pdf |archivedate=October 2, 2016 }}</ref> * Also on November 14, 2009, a newly built 42-inch gas transmission pipeline near [[Philo, Ohio]] failed on the second day of operation. There was no fire, but evacuations resulted. Several indications of pipe deformation were found.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2009-1024H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320091024H/320091024H_CAO_02172010.pdf?nocache=1083 |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304070254/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320091024H/320091024H_CAO_02172010.pdf?nocache=1083 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2009-1024H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320091024H/320091024H_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20CAO_12212009.pdf |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211184749/https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/Comm/reports/enforce/documents/320091024H/320091024H_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20CAO_12212009.pdf |archivedate=February 11, 2017 }}</ref> * From December 3 to 4, a [[Minnesota Pipeline]] carrying crude oil leaked in [[Todd County, Minnesota]], spilling about 5,000 barrels of crude. Pipeline workers on December 3 had been repairing sections of the 16-inch pipe in a rural area, left on the afternoon of December 3, and the spill occurred during the evening hours of December 3–4.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://energypipelinenews.blogspot.com/2009/12/kochs-mpc-line-spills-210000-gallons-of.html |title=Energy Pipeline News |author=Noel Griese |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218170946/http://energypipelinenews.blogspot.com/2009/12/kochs-mpc-line-spills-210000-gallons-of.html |archivedate=December 18, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/273107 |title=Dec. 4, 2009 – ProPublica |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151031141013/http://projects.propublica.org/pipelines/incidents/273107 |archivedate=October 31, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.staplesworld.com/news/2009-12-10/front_page/001.html |title=Pipeline leaks 210,000 gallons of oil – www.staplesworld.com – Staples World |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016232028/http://www.staplesworld.com/news/2009-12-10/front_page/001.html |archivedate=October 16, 2014}}</ref> * On December 23, a crude oil pipeline started leaking in [[Galveston, Texas]]. There was no fire or explosion as a result of the accident, and an estimated {{convert|120|oilbbl|m3}} of crude oil were released to the environment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration – September 29, 2010 |url=http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/Enterprise%20HL%20TX%202009-12-23.pdf |accessdate=27 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127215948/http://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles/PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/Enterprise%20HL%20TX%202009-12-23.pdf |archivedate=November 27, 2016 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} {{List of pipeline accidents in the United States|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Lists of pipeline accidents in the United States]] [[Category:2009 disasters in the United States]]

revision.text:
This article is a '''list of diseases''' of cultivated [[wild rice]] (''Zizania palustris''). Fungal Brown Spot is the only significant commercial disease of cultivated wild rice, it is found mostly in the cultivated wild rice fields of Minnesota. ==Bacterial diseases== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Bacterial diseases'''
|- |Bacterial brown spot ||''[[Pseudomonas syringae]]'' pv. ''syringae'' |- |Bacterial leaf streak ||''[[Xanthomonas campestris]]'' ''[[Pseudomonas coronafaciens]]'' pv. ''zizaniae'' |- |} ==Fungal diseases== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Fungal diseases'''
|- |Anthracnose || ''[[Colletotrichum sublineolum]]'' |- |Ergot || ''[[Claviceps zizaniae]]'' |- |Fungal brown spot || ''[[Bipolaris oryzae]]'' |- |Phytophthora crown and root rot || ''[[Phytophthora erythroseptica]]'' |- |Scab || ''[[Fusarium]]'' spp. |- |Spot blotch || ''[[Bipolaris sorokiniana]]'' |- |Stem rot || ''[[Sclerotium hydrophilum]]''
''[[Sclerotium oryzae]]'' |- |Stem smut || ''[[Entyloma lineatum]]'' |- |Zonate eye spot || ''[[Drechslera gigantea]]'' |- |} ==Viral diseases== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Viral diseases'''
|- |Wheat streak mosaic ||[[Wheat streak mosaic virus]]—wild rice |- |} ==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070202091622/http://www.apsnet.org/online/common/names/wildrice.asp Common Names of Diseases, The American Phytopathological Society] [[Category:Lists of plant diseases|Wild rice]]

revision.text:
[[File:Saint-Martin-de-Fressengeas Harzburgit2.jpg|right|250px|thumb|Metaharzburgite from the [[Rebière Massif]], [[Saint-Martin-de-Fressengeas]], [[Dordogne, France]]. The nearly upright magmatic (slightly South dipping) flow foliation parallels the hammer shaft.]]
'''Magmatic foliation''' is a term in [[geology]], for [[Foliation (geology)|foliation]] in [[granitoid]]s that form by [[magmatic]] flow, "submagmatic flow," by high-temperature solid-state [[Deformation (geology)|deformation]] and moderate- to low-temperature solid-state deformation.<ref name="sciencedirect.com">ScienceDirect: [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0191814189900746 Foliations in granitoids can form by magmatic flow, ‘submagmatic flow’, high-temperature solid-state deformation and moderate- to low-temperature solid-state deformation. A], accessdate: March 23, 2017</ref>
Remember, [[granitoids]] are [[igneous rock]]s.<ref name="springer.com">Springer: [https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-662-03000-4_10 Metamorphism of Granitoids - Springer], accessdate: March 23, 2017</ref><ref name="berkeley.edu">Granite: [https://nature.berkeley.edu/classes/eps2/wisc/granite.html metamo], accessdate: March 23, 2017</ref>
==See also==
* [[Foliation (geology)]]
